Problem:
Let's consider a complex-valued function \\( z(t) \\) that evolves according to the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial}{\\partial t}z = i\\omega z \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a constant frequency. We investigate the influence of the Fourier transformation \\( F(z) \\) defined by \\( \\hat{z}(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty z(t) e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\).

If \\( F(z) \\) is applied to a function \\( z(t) = e^{i\\omega t} \\) at \\( t = 0 \\) and the resulting function is then allowed to evolve under \\( \\frac{\\partial}{\\partial t}z = i\\omega z \\) without further intervention, will the time evolution of \\( \\hat{z}(\\omega) \\) at any later time \\( T \\) be equivalent to if the function \\( z(t) \\) was directly evolved without the Fourier transform?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of \\( z(t) = e^{i\\omega t} \\) is a delta function centered at the frequency \\( \\omega \\), and the evolution \\( \\frac{\\partial}{\\partial t}z = i\\omega z \\) will maintain the form of \\( z(t) \\). Hence the Fourier transform remains unaltered over time.

causal_map_integration: The time evolution of \( z(t) \) directly influences its Fourier transform \( \hat{z}(\omega) \), and applying the Fourier transform followed by evolving \( \hat{z}(\omega) \) does not necessarily yield the same result as evolving \( z(t) \) directly.
